facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1962 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 10, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 716 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 10, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 716 of 1954.

facts.text: On June 17, 1930, Chathilal Sah of Sahebganj, owner of a house and two golas bearing holdings Nos. 184 and 185 in mahalla Sahebganj, executed a will bequeathing the property to daughter Parbati Kuer and nephew Ram Swarup in equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1930, Chathilal Sah of Sahebganj, who was the owner of a house and two golas bearing holdings Nos. 184 and 185 situated in mahalla Sahebganj, executed a will bequeathing the said property to his daughter Parbati Kuer and nephew Ram Swarup in equal shares.

facts.text: Under the will, Ram Swarup was to get the entire property if Parbati Kuer died unmarried or issueless.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said will Ram Swarup was to get the entire property in case Parbati Kuer died unmarried or issueless.

facts.text: On July 18, 1940, Ram Swarup sold one-half of the property to plaintiff-respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1940, Ram Swarup sold one-half of the said property to the plaintiff-respondent 1.

facts.text: On July 27, 1942, plaintiff-respondent 1 acquired under a patta some lands adjoining the property.

anchor.surface_text: On July 27, 1942, the plaintiff-respondent 1 acquired under a patta some lands adjoining the said property.

facts.text: On October 10, 1949, defendant 3 (respondent 3), alleging to be husband of Parbati Kuer, sold the remaining half of the disputed property to defendants 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: On October 10, 1949, defendant 3  respondent 3 herein , alleging to be the husband of the said Parbati Kuer, sold the remaining half of the disputed property to defendants 1 and 2.

facts.text: The land on which the house and golas stand is Dih-Basgit Lagani rent-paying land.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that the land on which the said house and golas stand is Dih-Basgit Lagani  rent-paying  land.

facts.text: On December 10, 1949, respondent 1 filed Title Suit No. 214 of 1949 in the First Court of the Munsif at Chapra for declaration of right to pre-empt the property purchased by appellants 1 and 2 and for directing transfer to him.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1949, respondent 1 filed Title Suit No. 214 of 1949 in the First Court of the Munsif at Chapra for a declaration that he has a right to pre-empt the property purchased by appellants 1 and 2 and for directing them to transfer the said property to him.

facts.text: In the suit, first appellant and his two sons were defendants 1, 2 and 2A, vendor was defendant 3.

anchor.surface_text: To that suit, the first appellant and his two sons were made defendants 1, 2 and 2A and their vendor was made defendant 3.

facts.text: Defendants contested the suit on grounds including that ceremonies of pre-emption were not performed and plaintiff not entitled under Mohamedan law as land was rent-paying.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants companytested the suit, inter alia, on the ground that the ceremonies of pre-emption were number performed and that under the Mohamedan, law the plaintiff was number entitled to pre-emption, as the land on which the said house and golas stood was rent-paying land.

facts.text: Learned Munsif dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsif dismissed the suit.

facts.text: On appeal, Subordinate Judge of Chapra allowed the appeal and granted decree for pre-emption to plaintiff-respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: But, on appeal the Subordinate Judge of Chapra allowed the appeal and granted a decree for pre-emption in favour of the plaintiff-respondent 1.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Subordinate Judge and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court agreed with the Subordinate Judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Defendants 1, 2 and 2A preferred present appeal by special leave against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 1, 2 and 2A have preferred the present appeal by special leave against the Judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Ceremonies of pre-emption were performed on October 11, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the ceremonies of pre- emption were performed only on October 11, 1949 whereas the sale deed in favour of the appellants was executed and registered on October 20, 1949

facts.text: Sale deed executed and registered on October 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the sale deed in favour of the appellants was executed and registered on October 20, 1949

facts.text: Munsif dismissed suit on April 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsif dismissed the suit on April 14, 1953.

facts.text: Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

facts.text: Hindus in Bihar adopted Mohamedan law of pre-emption as custom.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been disputed that Hindus in the Province of Bihar came to adopt the Mohamedan law of pre-emption as a custom.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside decrees of Subordinate Judge and High Court, restores trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decrees of the Subordinate Judges Court and the High Court are set aside and that of the trial Court is restored.

facts.text: Right of pre-emption does not exist for leasehold interest or house on such land under Mohamedan law as applied by custom in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the first respondent has numberright to pre-empt the sale executed in favour of the appellants.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 10, 1958, of the Patna High Court
